z:row.TitlePrimary: Plasma engineering considerations for TASKA-M
z:row.TitleSecondary: 10th Symposium on Fusion Engineering Proceedings (Cat. No. 83CH1916-6 NPS), 5-9 Dec. 1983
z:row.TitleTertiary: 10th Symposium on Fusion Engineering Proceedings (Cat. No. 83CH1916-6 NPS)
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor theory and design|magnetic mirrors|plasma heating|plasma instability
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Philadelphia, PA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Power Associates, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: TASKA-M is a tandem mirror facility aimed at technology and materials testing with reactor-relevant neutron fluxes and fluences. A high neutron wall loading (1.3 MW/m2) is obtained locally in the central cell using neutral beam injection at 45° to produce a sloshing ion distribution. The total fusion power is only 6.8 MW. Electron heating using Landau damping of ion cyclotron waves produces an electron temperature high enough to minimize the electron drag on the hot ions. The resulting potential well in the central cell is deep enough to contain a warm plasma which stabilizes the hot mirror-confined plasma against the DCLC mode. MHD stability is obtained by yin-yang anchors at each end of the central cell
z:row.User2: plasma engineering considerations; electron heating; TASKA-M; tandem mirror facility; reactor-relevant neutron fluxes; high neutron wall loading; central cell; neutral beam injection; sloshing ion distribution; total fusion power; ion cyclotron waves; electron temperature; electron drag; hot mirror-confined plasma; MHD stability; yin-yang anchors

z:row.TitlePrimary: NEW METHOD TO MEASURE PLASMA POTENTIAL WITH EMISSIVE PROBES
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Dep of Nuclear Engineering, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Abstract: A new method of measuring the plasma potential using emissive probes is presented; the 'droop' method. This method may be used in a steady-state experiment in which T//e VM GT TH T//w, where T//e and T//w are the electron and filament temperatures, respectively. The method is based on the observation that the floating potential of an emissive probe depends on T//w. A filament temperature which changes in time causes the floating potential also to vary. The proportionality constant between the two is extremely sensitive to whether the probe is above or below the plasma potential. Thus, a floating emissive probe which is allowed to cool can be used to discriminate between voltages above and below the space potential.

z:row.Abstract: A preliminary design of a 5500 MWth modular stellarator power reactor, UWTOR-M, is presented. The authors briefly describe the parametric considerations which led to the UWTOR-M reference design point. The natural stellarator divertor is used for impurity control in conjunction with innovative high performance divertor targets. A unique blanket design is proposed which minimizes tritium inventory in the reactor. Finally, since maintainability is a prime consideration, the authors describe a scheme for servicing the first wall/blanket and other reactor components

z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion React Mater, Part B, Proc of the 3rd Top Meet, Sep 19-22 1983

z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Albuquerque, NM, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Power Associates, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The design of a low power (6. 8 MW) tandem mirror technology test facility is given. The facility is based on physics presently in hand or that should be available by 1985. Technologies employed by TASKA-M are at the mid-1980's level and the device is designed to achieve a peak damage level of approx. 78 dpa in two materials test modules which have a test volume of approx. 170 liters. In addition, two modules are reserved for blanket testing at nominal wall loadings of approx. 1 MW/m**2. The direct cost of TASKA-M is less than 400 million dollars, making it an attractive next step beyond MFTF-B.

z:row.TitlePrimary: WITAMIR-I: A tandem mirror power reactor
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fusion Reactor Design and Technology. Proceedings of the 3rd Technical Committee Meeting and Workshop, 5-16 Oct. 1981
z:row.TitleTertiary: Fusion Reactor Design and Technology. Proceedings of the 3rd Technical Committee Meeting and Workshop
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor materials|fusion reactor theory and design
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Tokyo, Japan
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A conceptual design of a near term commercial tandem mirror power reactor is presented. The basic configuration utilizes Yin-yang minimum B end plugs with inboard thermal barriers, which are pumped by neutral beam injection. The maximum magnetic fields are 6.1 T, 8.1 T and 15 T in the central cell, Yin-yang, and thermal barrier magnets, respectively. The blanket utilizes Pb83Li17 as the coolant and breeder, and HT-9 as the structural material. This configuration yields a high energy multiplication (1.37), a sufficient tritium breeding ratio (1.07) and has a major advantage with respect to maintenance. A single stage direct convertor is used at one end and an electron thermal dump at the other end. The plasma Q is 28 at a fusion power level of 3000 MWth; the net electrical output is 1530 MWe and the overall efficiency is 39%. Cost estimates indicate that WITAMIR-I is competitive with recent tokamak power reactor designs
z:row.User2: 3H breeding; WITAMIR-I; tandem mirror power reactor; design; thermal barriers; neutral beam injection; magnetic fields; blanket; Pb83Li17; coolant; fusion power level; efficiency

z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the Second Topical Meeting on Fusion Reactor Materials, 9-12 Aug. 1981
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Seattle, WA, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The preliminary performance of a new Engineering Testing Reactor based on the tandem mirror confinement principle is described. This device, called TASKA, is based on near term (mid 1980s) technology and is designed to test reactor relevant technologies (superconducting magnets, blankets, materials, etc.) for the Demonstration Power Reactor envisioned for the turn of the century. The key operating parameters are a DT power level of 86 MW, a neutron wall loading of 1.5 MW/m2, and an overall tritium breeding ratio of 1.0. Details of the materials testing program reveal that damage levels approaching 100 dpa can be achieved in less than 15 years of irradiation time. TASKA appears to be an attractive, cost effective way of achieving the near term technology testing goals for the world fusion program
z:row.User2: TASKA; fusion engineering test facility; Engineering Testing Reactor; tandem mirror confinement principle; superconducting magnets; blankets; materials; Demonstration Power Reactor; DT power level; neutron wall loading; tritium breeding ratio

z:row.TitlePrimary: THEORETICAL MODEL FOR HOT PLASMA FLOWING TO A WALL WITH RECYCLING
z:row.TitleSecondary: Plasma Surf Interact in Controlled Fusion Devices, Proc of the Int Conf, 5th, May 3-7 1982
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Gatlinburg, TN, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Dep of Nuclear Engineering, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Abstract: Plasma flow along field lines to material walls is a common property of divertors and limiters where the plasma is neutralized at a target plate. A theoretical model to describe the hot plasma flowing to the wall, where it is neutralized, and the cold plasma produced by ionization of thermal neutrals has been developed. A necessary ingredient in this model is the electrostatic potential, which turns out to tbe positive near the wall (relative to further in the plasma) before dropping the sheath. The treatment is kinetic rather than fluid-like and largely analytic. The results agree well with a numerical kinetic calculation by Morse and co-workers for a uniform field case.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: DIVERTORS; LIMITERS

z:row.TitlePrimary: UWTOR-M - A CONCEPTUAL DESIGN STUDY OF A MODULAR STELLARATOR POWER REACTOR
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison, USA
z:row.Abstract: A preliminary design of a 5500 MW//t//h modular stellarator power reactor, UWTOR-M, is presented. Discrete twisted coils are used in an l equals 3 configuration with maintainability as a prime consideration. The natural stellarator divertor is used for impurity control in conjunction with innovative high performance divertor targets. A unique blanket design is proposed which minimizes the overall tritium inventory in the reactor. Finally, a scheme for maintaining the first wall/blanket and other reactor components is discussed.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: NON-AMBIPOLAR TRANSPORT IN A MAGNETIC DIVERTOR
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison, USA
z:row.Abstract: An important problem in current tokamak research is impurity control, namely, how to keep impurities out of the main plasma discharge. Some proposed solutions are low-Z liners (or coatings on a liner), pumped limiters, and magnetic divertors. Plasma transport is studied in a simulated magnetic divertor in the Wisconsin single-ring dc machine. The transport perpendicular and parallel to the magnetic field is shown to be non-ambipolar by a variety of measurements.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Plasma transport and impurity behaviour in the edge and divertor regions of a Tokamak
z:row.TitleSecondary: Eighth International Conference on Plasma Physics and Controlled Nuclear Fusion Research, 1-10 July 1980
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor theory and design|Monte Carlo methods|plasma confinement|plasma impurities|plasma instability|plasma magnetohydrodynamics|plasma transport processes|Tokamak devices
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Brussels, Belgium
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A number of issues regarding impurity behaviour and plasma transport in the edge and divertor regions of a Tokamak are discussed. With regard to plasma edge and divertor effects: (1) the experimentally observed radial plasma transport is shown to significantly exceed estimates of that induced by the resistive MHD instabilities; (2) parallel mass transport into a bundle divertor is shown to be inhibited by the magnetic mirror at the divertor entrance; (3) an experimental test of the gaseous divertor concept in the QED has demonstrated a factor of 102 pressure differential and a reduction of conductance by a factor of 10; (4) a Monte-Carlo calculation of pumping by a poloidal divertor box indicates that the pumping is 1.6 to 4.3 times more efficient for hydrogen than for helium; (5) a new edge model for helium, however, including the very rapid recycling, indicates that significantly less helium pumping may be required than previously thought; and (6) variations in the energy of recycled neutrals are shown to have a large effect on the edge plasma and a noticeable effect on the central temperature
z:row.User2: Tokamak divertor region; Monte Carlo calculation; He pumping; controlled thermonuclear fusion; impurity behaviour; plasma transport; resistive MHD instabilities; parallel mass transport; bundle divertor; magnetic mirror; gaseous divertor concept; QED; poloidal divertor box; edge model; rapid recycling; edge plasma; central temperature

z:row.TitlePrimary: Plasma engineering considerations for an inside-barrier Tandem Mirror Test Facility
z:row.TitleSecondary: 9th Symposium on Engineering Problems of Fusion Research, 26-29 Oct. 1981
z:row.TitleTertiary: 9th Symposium on Engineering Problems of Fusion Research
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Chicago, IL, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The effects of technology limitations on the design of a tandem mirror, aimed at testing materials and pertinent reactor technology on a 1990s time scale, are presented. Parameters for a reference case device and parametric variation of some important quantities are magnetic field limits, neutral beam injection angles, ECRH and ICRH systems, alpha particle removal, fueling, and stability criterion
z:row.User2: inside-barrier Tandem Mirror Test Facility; technology limitations; design; parametric variation; magnetic field limits; neutral beam injection angles; ECRH; ICRH; alpha particle removal; fueling; stability criterion

z:row.TitlePrimary: UWTOR-M, a conceptual design study of a modular stellarator power reactor
z:row.TitleSecondary: 9th Symposium on Engineering Problems of Fusion Research, 26-29 Oct. 1981
z:row.TitleTertiary: 9th Symposium on Engineering Problems of Fusion Research
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Chicago, IL, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A preliminary design of a 5500 MWth modular stellarator power reactor, UWTOR-M, is presented. The authors briefly describe the parametric considerations which led to the UWTOR-M reference design point. The design has 18 twisted coils utilizing a multipolarity of 3, a major radius of 24 m, a coil radius of 4.77 m and a plasma aspect ratio of 14. An assumed β of 5% was used. This configuration leads to a rotational transform on the edge of 1.125 giving favourable plasma physics conditions. The natural stellarator divertor is used for impurity control in conjunction with innovative high performance divertor targets. A unique blanket design is proposed which minimizes tritium inventory in the reactor. Finally, since maintainability is a prime consideration, we describe a scheme for servicing the first wall/blanket and other reactor components
z:row.User2: UWTOR-M; design study; modular stellarator power reactor; multipolarity; rotational transform; stellarator divertor; blanket design

z:row.TitlePrimary: Electric sheath and presheath in a collisionless, finite ion temperature plasma
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The plasma-sheath equation for a collisionless plasma with arbitrary ion temperature in plane geometry is formulated. Outside the sheath, this equation is approximated by the plasma equation, for which an analytic solution for the electrostatic potential is obtained. In addition, the ion distribution function, the wall potential, and the ion energy and particle flux into the sheath are explicitly calculated. The plasma-sheath equation is also solved numerically with no approximation of the Debye length. The numerical results compare well with the analytical results when the Debye length is small
z:row.User2: presheath; finite ion temperature plasma; electrostatic potential; ion distribution function; plasma sheath equation

z:row.TitlePrimary: PLASMA FLOW AND NEUTRAL GAS EFFECTS IN THE BUNDLE DIVERTOR CHAMBER
z:row.TitleSecondary: Plasma Surf Interact in Controlled Fusion Devices, Proc of the Int Conf, 4th, Apr 21-25 1980
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Garmisch-Partenkirchen, W Ger
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison
z:row.Abstract: A magnetic mirror in the entrance to the divertor chamber affects the flow of plasma from the scrape-off zone into the divertor chamber and the backflow of ions from the divertor chamber into the main chamber. The magnetic hill and subsequent well causes an electrostatic potential along the field lines; this traps cold ions in the divertor chamber. Ionization of neutral gas in the divertor chamber reduces the electrostatic well; maintaining a well implies an upper limit on the neutral gas density. The effect of ionization on the potential profile is calculated and an estimate of the allowable neutral pressure is given.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: SPUDNUT: A transport code for neutral atoms in plasmas
z:row.Keyword: physics computing|plasma collision processes|plasma simulation|plasma transport processes
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nuclear Engng., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The problem of neutral atom transport in plasmas is formulated in terms of an integral equation for the charge exchange collision density. This formulation is used as the basis for a numerical code, SPUDNUT, which is exceptionally fast and compact. Comparative calculations with other neutral particle transport codes are presented
z:row.User2: SPUDNUT; transport code; plasmas; neutral atom transport; integral equation; charge exchange collision density; numerical code

z:row.TitlePrimary: Simultaneous feedback stabilization of two flute modes of similar frequency
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A multimode feedback stabilization system which separates the modes by their spatial variation has been developed and used successfully in an experiment in which the m=1 and m=2 flute modes can exist simultaneously with almost the same frequency in the laboratory frame. The system allows separate control of each mode and, therefore, can be a useful diagnostic tool. An interesting result is the observation of the nonlinear coupling between the m=1 and m=2 modes. The m=1 mode apparently has a strong quenching effect on the m=2 mode
z:row.User2: two flute modes; multimode feedback stabilization system; nonlinear coupling; strong quenching effect

z:row.TitlePrimary: Observation of ultralow frequency oscillations in the trapped electron regime
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Large scale near zero frequency, oscillations are observed in the linear multimirror experiment when the plasma is unstable to two dissipative trapped electron modes simultaneously. The oscillations are flutelike and may be either coherent or turbulent
z:row.User2: ultralow frequency oscillations; trapped electron regime; linear multimirror experiment; dissipative trapped electron modes; plasma instability; plasma oscillations

z:row.TitlePrimary: Trapped electron instability in a linear multi-mirror experiment
z:row.Keyword: magnetic mirrors|plasma diagnostics|plasma instability|plasma temperature|plasma transport processes
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The dissipative trapped electron instability is observed in the linear multi-mirror experiment. This instability is observed in two forms, one driven by the electron temperature gradient, and one driven by finite Larmor radius effects. The experimental results are in reasonable agreement with the theoretical predictions of the linear dispersion relation
z:row.User2: electron temperature gradient; finite Larmor radius effects; linear dispersion relation; trapped electron instability; linear multimirror experiment; dissipative instability

z:row.TitlePrimary: Experimental transfer function analysis of a dissipative and a reactive mode
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Experimental measurements of the transfer function of both a dissipative and a reactive instability in the same device-the Linear Multi-Mirror experiment-are reported. The results illustrate clearly the dissipative and reactive nature of each mode and are consistent with the theoretical form of the transfer function
z:row.User2: transfer function analysis; reactive mode; reactive instability; linear multi mirror experiment; dissipative instability

z:row.TitlePrimary: Transfer function analysis of a stable and feedback-stabilized plasma
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The transfer function of a magnetic mirror plasma containing a feedback loop is measured experimentally. The measurements are obtained in a configuration where 1) the interchange mode is weakly damped, and 2) the interchange mode is unstable, but stabilized by the feedback loop. The results are in good agreement with the theoretically derived transfer function involving parameters (e.g. damping rates) determined by fitting the theoretical curve to the data. This method of analysis has diagnostic utility for mode identification and the measurement of damping rates
z:row.User2: transfer function; magnetic mirror plasma; feedback loop; interchange mode; damping rates; diagnostic utility; mode identification; damping rate measurements; diagnostics

z:row.TitlePrimary: A high-performance non-circular Tokamak power reactor design study-UWMAK-III
z:row.TitleSecondary: 6th International Conference on Plasma Physics and Controlled Nuclear Fusion Research, vol.III, 6-13 Oct. 1976
z:row.Keyword: design engineering|fusion reactors|maintenance engineering|nuclear power stations|Tokamak devices
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Berchtesgaden, West Germany
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Nuclear Engng., Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Advanced technologies studied include the use of the molybdenum-based alloy, TZM, as the primary structural material, the use of aluminium as the stabilizer and aluminium alloy structure for the NbTi superconducting magnets, and the use of a closed-cycle helium gas turbine power conversion system. New or different design approaches include the study of RF (fast magnetosonic waves) plasma heating, a blanket design where tritium breeding is accomplished only in the outer blanket region, a permanent inner blanket that is basically a hot shield, tritium extraction and recycling processes, and the general design approach to blanket module removal. The maximum module weight is only 42 t. An MHD analysis has determined the non-circular plasma shaped like a characteristic `D' with neutral points on the plasma boundary for a poloidal divertor. The reactor is small (major radius =8.1 m) with a relatively high β (about 9%) and an average neutron wall loading of 2.5 MW.m-2. It is designed to generate 5000 MW(th) during the burn and 1985 MW(e) continuously. The net plant efficiency is about 42%
z:row.User2: Tokamak power reactor design; UWMAK-III; TZM; structural material; gas turbine power conversion; RF; fast magnetosonic waves; plasma heating; blanket design; extraction; recycling; blanket module removal; MHD analysis; poloidal divertor; high performance; noncircular; He closed cycle; T breeding; Mo alloy; Al alloy

z:row.TitlePrimary: Transport model for a Tokamak reactor with a poloidal divertor
z:row.TitleSecondary: 1976 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science. (Abstracts only received), 24-26 May 1976
z:row.TitleTertiary: 1976 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science. (Abstracts only received)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Austin, TX, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Discusses the density, electron and ion temperature profiles for a Tokamak plasma onto which a magnetic field divertor is attached. By modeling the divergence of the particle and energy loss along the magnetic field lines in the divertor zone using grad∥×Γ∥→Γ∥(r)/L(r) one can construct a cylindrical (two region) time dependent code to do just such a calculation. Results are presented on profiles and how effectively the divertor screens the plasma core region from impurities. For large Tokamak devices a good unload divertor and a good shielding divertor are not mutually exclusive. There appears to be a relatively narrow region of average plasma densities which produce thermally stable `equilibria' when using the trapped particle modes to model the diffusion processes
z:row.User2: Tokamak reactor; poloidal divertor; ion temperature profiles; magnetic field divertor; unload divertor; shielding divertor; trapped particle modes; diffusion processes; density profile; electron temperature profile; impurity screen; plasma transport model

z:row.TitlePrimary: Removal of impurities from Tokamaks by neutral-beam injection
z:row.Keyword: plasma collision processes|plasma confinement|plasma transport processes|plasma-beam interactions
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nuclear Engng., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Based on the drift-kinetic equation with a Fokker-Planck treatment of the interaction of the beam with various species in the plasma, the authors present a calculation of additional impurity diffusion due to collisions with the neutral beam. The relevance of the theory to confinement problems is discussed
z:row.User2: Tokamaks; impurity diffusion; confinement problems; plasma diffusion; impurity removal; drift kinetic equation; neutral beam injection; plasma collisions

z:row.TitlePrimary: Mirror microinstabilities in divertors
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nuclear Engng., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Impurity control in Tokamaks may be implemented by the use of a divertor. The plasma in the divertor region may however, be unstable to minor microinstabilities which may affect plasma transport in this region
z:row.User2: Tokamaks; divertor; minor microinstabilities; plasma transport; impurity control

z:row.TitlePrimary: Feedback stabilization of reactive instabilities
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The general theory of linear feedback stabilization of reactive instabilities is extended to include the effects of dissipation in the plasma and frequency-dependence in the sensor suppressor elements and in the external feedback circuit. The theory is in agreement with experiments performed using the flute instability in a magnetic mirror as a model. One noteworthy result is that frequency-dependence in the overall gain and phase shift of the feedback loop can cause destabilization at large gain
z:row.User2: feedback stabilization; reactive instabilities; general theory of linear feedback stabilization; dissipation; sensor suppressor elements; external feedback circuit; flute instability; magnetic mirror

z:row.TitlePrimary: Major design features of the conceptual D-T Tokamak power reactor, UWMAK-II
z:row.TitleSecondary: 5th International Conference on Plasma Physics and Controlled Nuclear Fusion Research, 11-15 Nov. 1974
z:row.TitleTertiary: 5th International Conference on Plasma Physics and Controlled Nuclear Fusion Research
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Tokyo, Japan
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Technol. Program, Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The conceptual design of a 5000 MW(th)(~1700 MW(e)) helium-cooled Tokamak fusion reactor is presented. The fuel is deuterium and tritium and the structural material is 316 stainless steel. The design has a low aspect ratio (2.6) and low toroidal field on axis (35.7 kG) with 24 extended `D'-shaped superconducting TF coils. A superconducting air core transformer is designed with windings outside TF coils while the vertical field magnets, also superconducting, are inside the extended `Ds'. The plasma operating conditions have been determined using pessimistic scaling laws resulting from trapped-ion instability
z:row.User2: Tokamak power reactor; UWMAK-II; aspect ratio; toroidal field; superconducting air core transformer; scaling laws; He cooling; D-T fusion reactor

z:row.TitlePrimary: Finite-β stabilization of flute-like microinstabilities
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The stability of a finite-β plasma with density and temperature gradients located in a cylindrically symmetric azimuthal magnetic field is investigated using the Vlasov-Maxwell set of equations. The frequency is assumed to be low but finite gyroradius and wave-guiding centre resonance effects are retained. It is found that β can both stabilize and destabilize the fast flute mode depending on the gradients, but has no effect on the temperature gradient mode. The interchange mode is essentially unaffected by β. This latter result is in agreement with results from fluid models, as one might expect
z:row.User2: cylindrically symmetric azimuthal magnetic field; finite beta stabilization; flutelike microinstabilities; Vlasov Maxwell equations; plasma

z:row.TitlePrimary: First wall surface problems for a D-T tokamak reactor
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the conference on surface effects in controlled thermonuclear fusion devices and reactors, 10-12 Jan. 1974
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Argonne, IL, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The effects of deuterium, tritium, helium and neutron bombardment on surface degradation of the first wall of a 5000 MWth D-T reactor have been analyzed. The effects of both sputtering and blistering have been analyzed and the results applied to 316 stainless steel wall operating at temperatures from 300 to 500°C. It has been calculated that the total wall erosion rate is 0.22 mm/year and that 14 MeV neutron sputtering accounts for two thirds of this number. Sputtering from all neutrons results in ≈0.17 mm/year erosion. The calculated erosion rate is 2-3 times that which would be allowable for a 30 year first wall lifetime
z:row.User2: surface degradation; first wall; sputtering; blistering; 316 stainless steel wall; total wall erosion rate; DT Tokamak reactor

z:row.TitleSecondary: 1st Topical Meeting on the Technology of Controlled Nuclear Fusion (abstracts only received), 16-18 April 1974

z:row.Abstract: The Wisconsin Tokamak reactor design (UWMAK-I) incorporates a poloidal divertor to establish a plasma boundary away from the first wall and to reduce wall erosion by energetic charged particle bombardment and the subsequent release of impurities into the plasma. z:row.TitlePrimary: Properties and solutions of the steady-state neoclassical transport equations
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Some results on the properties and solutions of the steady-state form of the neoclassical transport equations are presented for regimes of interest to feasibility experiments and reactors. An analytical solution is obtained for the special case dT/dr=0. For dT/dr≠0, an analytic solution is found for the particle density n(r) in terms of the current j(r) and the temperature T(r). For a prescribed j(r), a single differential equation remains to find the temperature profile

z:row.TitlePrimary: Education and research in controlled fusion at the University of Wisconsin
z:row.TitleSecondary: 1973 Annual Meeting of the American Nuclear Society (Summaries), 10-14 June 1973
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Chicago, IL, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The plasma physics aspect of the controlled fusion program at the University of Wisconsin began in 1962. The technological aspects of CTR began to receive some attention starting about 1967 and grew to a full-scale effort in 1971 when the fusion design team was formed. This team is composed of about 15 representing the various disciplines of plasma physics, neutronics, materials, heat transfer, stress analysis, chemical engineering, and superconductivity. The initial task of the design team has been to establish a conceptual design of a Tokamak fusion reactor to better assess the technological problems that may be encountered. The plasma physics curriculum has a core of three courses. The first of these is an introductory course open to undergraduates as well as graduate students. The two remaining courses are taught at the advanced graduate level after the student has a better background to classical mechanics and electrodynamics
z:row.User2: education; research; controlled fusion; plasma physics; neutronics; materials; heat transfer; stress analysis; chemical engineering; superconductivity; plasma physics curriculum; introductory course; undergraduates; graduate students; Wisconsin University; teaching

z:row.Abstract: A scoping design has been carried out to determine the technological problems associated with the low β Tokamak approach to reactors. z:row.TitlePrimary: Self-consistent energy balance studies for CTR Tokamak plasmas
z:row.TitleSecondary: Texas Symposium on the Technology of Controlled Thermonuclear Fusion Experiments and the Engineering Aspects of Fusion Reactors. (Abstracts only received), 20-22 Nov. 1972
z:row.TitleTertiary: Texas Symposium on the Technology of Controlled Thermonuclear Fusion Experiments and the Engineering Aspects of Fusion Reactors. (Abstracts only received)
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactors|magnetic traps|plasma stability|thermonuclear reactions|Tokamak devices
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: Austin, TX, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The equations required to study the dependence of the steady state operating conditions in a tokamak-like CTR plasma on various system parameters are solved. Particle diffusion is explicitly represented by neo-classical theory and βp, the ratio of plasma pressure to poloidal magnetic field pressure, is limited to a maximum value, of √A, where A is the aspect ratio. The particle and energy balance equations are solved self-consistently with the confinement time equation and the constraint equation on plasma pressure. The dependence of the plasma operating parameters on enhanced bremsstrahlung radiation losses and enhanced diffusional losses is studied. A viable tokamak-like CTR plasma is suggested consistent with the parametric study
z:row.User2: steady state operating conditions; particle diffusion; plasma pressure; poloidal magnetic field pressure; confinement time equation; enhanced bremsstrahlung radiation losses; enhanced diffusional losses; self consistent energy balance; controlled thermonuclear reactor tokamak plasma; neoclassical theory

z:row.TitlePrimary: Flutelike instabilities in a strongly curved magnetic field
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: For three different distribution functions, the analysis of low-frequency flutelike instabilities of a low-β collisionless plasma immersed in the magnetic field of a line current indicates that the qualitative characteristics of the instabilities are independent of the distribution function. The analysis is valid for arbitrary curvature in the absence of magnetic shear and mirror effects. Numerical results for the growth rate phase velocity for one of the distribution functions illustrate the behavior of the various instabilities, and comparison with Taylor's minimum-b theorem shows which particles in velocity space provide the energy to drive the instabilities
z:row.User2: low beta collisionless plasma; flutelike instabilities; strongly curved magnetic field; distribution functions; arbitrary curvature; mirror effects

z:row.TitlePrimary: Curvature stabilization of the universal instability
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A graphical technique for determining the influence of the drift velocity in a magnetic well on wave-particle resonance is presented and applied to the universal instability. It is seen that the curvature drift velocity can strongly affect the number of resonant ions and lead to increased stabilization of the wave
z:row.User2: curvature stabilization; wave particle resonance; plasma; universal instability; drift velocity; magnetic well

z:row.TitlePrimary: Temperature gradients, resonance, and the interchange instability
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Temperature gradients and wave-guiding center resonance modify the modify the usual finite gyroradius stabilization criteria and growth rate for the interchange instability in a collisionless low-β plasma. The growth rate is given for a few examples
